title: DeMarcus Cousins reiterates desire to play his entire career with Kings
text:
February 16, 2017 10:04 PM DeMarcus Cousins reiterates desire to play his entire career with Kings Intense effort to fortify Lake Oroville continues in rough weather 1:09 These dams loom large in Northern California's water world 3:58 Boulders, concrete flown in to strengthen damaged Oroville spillway 0:58 Watch: Drone flies over auxiliary spillway at Lake Oroville 2:29 49ers GM John Lynch speaks at presser 0:25 Meanwhile, at Shasta Dam... maximum water releases, storage at 95% and storms on the way 0:24 From the air, ruined landscape clearly shows effect of Oroville Dam spillway problem 1:57 Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom says spillway failure a wake-up call 1:43 Yolo prosecutor announces arrest of Davis woman in hate crime targeting Islamic Center Share Video email The Sacramento Kings added two more players to their list of injured during Wednesday’s 109-86 loss to the Golden State Warriors at Oracle Arena after Arron Afflalo and Malachi Richardson both left the game with injuries. Jason Jones The Sacramento Bee Kings forward DeMarcus Cousins, right, hugs teammate Darren Collison after a win over the Atlanta Hawks at Golden 1 Center in Sacramento, California on Friday, Feb. 10, 2017. Hector Amezcua hamezcua@sacbee.com 1 of 2 
clamarr@sacbee.com 
DeMarcus Cousins wants to stay in Sacramento. For his entire career. 
The Kings power forward reiterated Thursday on ESPN’s “SportsCenter” that he intends to sign an extension with the team this summer, which The Sacramento Bee has previously reported. 
Cousins told ESPN that he wants his “legacy to end in Sacramento” and for his “jersey to be in the rafters in Sacramento.” 
RELATED: Kings face critical decision on Cousins 
Cousins, the fifth pick in the 2010 draft, is in his seventh season with the Kings. He has played for six head coaches in that time (Paul Westphal, Keith Smart, Michael Malone, Ty Corbin, George Karl and current coach Dave Joerger). Cousins, 26, can sign a five-year extension worth up to $219 million this summer. 
“I’m very happy. This is where I want to be,” Cousins said in the interview. 
The Kings (24-33) are 1 1/2 games behind Denver for the eighth and final playoff spot in the Western Conference. They have not made the playoffs since the 2005-06 season, and the most games they have won during Cousins’ tenure is 33, accomplished last season. 
“I think we’re on the right path this season,” Cousins told ESPN. “We’re playing the best basketball of the season so far. Our team is extremely confident. We believe we can make this push and make it happen.” 
Cousins, a three-time All-Star, is averaging career highs in points (27.8) and assists (4.8) this season.
